video.title: How the States Got Their Shapes
video.synopsis: Brian Unger hosts this clever road documentary series blending history, politics and geography to show how America's states got their current borders.

episodes.synopsis: As rivers and other waterways move and change course, states discover their boundaries are more fluid than they realized.
episodes.title: A River Runs Through It

episodes.synopsis: Learn how the history of transportation -- from canals to railways to freeways -- helped establish the boundaries of the states.
episodes.title: The Great Plains, Trains, & Automobiles

episodes.synopsis: Discover how asteroids, glaciers, earthquakes and other unstoppable forces of nature have influenced the boundaries of the map.
episodes.title: Force of Nature

episodes.synopsis: Regional attitudes, political rivalries and downright stubbornness have given Montana, Idaho and other states some unusually puzzling boundary lines.
episodes.title: State of Rebellion

episodes.synopsis: Even the best maps have some mysteries. What's hiding in the void of Area 51? What's the beef between Dade County and its home state, Georgia?
episodes.title: Living on the Edge

episodes.synopsis: Logic and careful planning often fall prey to political expediency when boundaries are established -- as in the case of Washington, D.C.
episodes.title: Use it or Lose It

episodes.synopsis: Discover how religion helped shape Utah and the New England states -- and how religious beliefs still hold sway in local gerrymandering today.
episodes.title: Church and States

episodes.synopsis: Discover how gold strikes, bank panics, free land and boom and bust economies have helped give Minnesota, North Dakota and other states their shapes.
episodes.title: A Boom with a View

episodes.synopsis: Culturally speaking, some states such as Maine and Florida are deeply divided -- could such rifts fracture some states in two?
episodes.title: Culture Clash

episodes.synopsis: Learn how regional accents, local slang and other verbal cues can act as "boundaries," creating cultural identities that may cross lines on a map.
episodes.title: Mouthing Off

episodes.synopsis: Host Brian Unger uncovers the surprisingly entertaining geographical, economic and political forces that literally shaped the states.
episodes.title: How the States Got Their Shapes

episodes.synopsis: The rivalry tears us apart every four years, but how did our nation become red states vs. blue states, and what happens to those caught in the middle?
episodes.title: Red State vs. Blue State

episodes.synopsis: In the Rust Belt, the white-collar and blue-collar divide shapes American cities and states. How does this change the way we all bring home the bacon?
episodes.title: White Collar vs. Blue Collar

episodes.synopsis: Two underdogs of American culture go head-to-head to prove how hillbillies and rednecks have shaped our states.
episodes.title: Hillbilly vs. Redneck

episodes.synopsis: America's most iconic rivalry was more than just a feud between families; the fight between the Hatfields and McCoys nearly launched a war.
episodes.title: Hatfields vs. McCoys

episodes.synopsis: It's America's original rivalry, a divide so wide it took a war to close the gap. But have we really reunited, or are we still fighting a culture war?
episodes.title: North vs. South

episodes.synopsis: America is under siege by unexplained phenomena. Whether you're afraid of Bigfoot or an alien invasion might depend on what state you call home.
episodes.title: Bigfoot vs. Aliens

episodes.synopsis: Battles over access to lakefront property have made the Great Lakes region the most contested land on the map, and even pushed states to a border war.
episodes.title: Great Lakes, Big Stakes

episodes.synopsis: With 85 percent of Americans affiliated with an organized religion, we're a nation of believers, but have we always practiced what we preach?
episodes.title: Battle of the Bible Belt

episodes.synopsis: Americans have a lot of vices and they don't just stay in Vegas. From drugs to gambling, the state you live in may shape how bad you can be.
episodes.title: Vice vs. Virtue

episodes.synopsis: It's the glue that holds our map together and feeds America, but the Midwest is more than just state fairs and flyover country.
episodes.title: Midwest vs. the Rest

episodes.synopsis: Americans have been racing to tame the West since they first set foot on the continent, but now that the West has been won, what's next?
episodes.title: Is West Best?

episodes.synopsis: In the battle between city and country, it looks like the city comes out ahead in population. But is there something the city slickers are missing?
episodes.title: City vs. Country

episodes.synopsis: The squabble between the coasts leaves the rest of the country stuck in the middle. Is there any common ground in this continental tug-of-war?
episodes.title: East vs. West

episodes.synopsis: We may be a law-abiding nation but we also admire the outlaw, and clashes between rebels and the rules have shaped our states.
episodes.title: Rebels & Outlaws

episodes.synopsis: Texas is the only state that acts like a country, but has it grown too big for its britches? We'll mess with Texas to settle this 10-gallon rivalry.
episodes.title: Mess with Texas

episodes.synopsis: It may be the United States, but sometimes it's every state for itself. Most states have pulled a power play to game the system and change the map.
episodes.title: State vs. State

episodes.synopsis: Money makes the world go round, and in America, the pursuit of riches has shaped our states. In the race for resources, which states came out on top?
episodes.title: Rich vs. Poor

episodes.synopsis: Does size matter when you're a state? While the giants like to throw their weight around, there are some scrappy underdogs that have made their mark.
episodes.title: Big vs. Small

episodes.synopsis: Brian Unger examines how American values have made the country what it is today, and what role those values played in shaping the states.
episodes.title: The United Shapes of America
